caseTitle: ERIC ANSONG VRS MR. ALBERT GORMAN, MRS. GORMAN 30TH DECEMBER, 2011
summary: This is a civil appeal before the Supreme Court of Ghana concerning the enforceability of a contract for the sale of property. The appellants, Mr. and Mrs. Gorman, challenged the Court of Appeal's affirmation of the High Court's decision ordering specific performance of a sale agreement allegedly entered into solely by Mr. Gorman, despite the property being jointly owned. The Supreme Court considered whether the contract was inchoate and unenforceable due to lack of consent from both co-owners, and whether the agreement was validly rescinded by the appellants prior to enforcement. The core issue centered on principles of contract law, co-ownership, and specific performance under Ghanaian property law.
verdict: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.
rationaleHighlights: The contract was unenforceable because it involved jointly owned property but only one co-owner was party to it.
A contract for sale of jointly owned property requires consent of all co-owners to be valid.
The appellants validly rescinded the agreement before completion, negating any subsisting obligation.
No circumstances existed that would make rescission fraudulent.
Specific performance cannot be granted on a non-binding or rescinded agreement.
